importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date of the incident and the release of the news, indicating when law enforcement acted to prevent a potential mass shooting at the Atlanta airport.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Cagle arrived at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport around 9:30 a.m., and the surveillance footage shows his arrival and movement toward the TSA checkpoint, indicating the critical time window when the threat was detected and acted upon.

keyTakeAways: A man, Billy Joe Cagle, a convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, planned to shoot up the world's busiest airport, Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, as revealed through a social media livestream.
Police were alerted by Cagle’s family, who reported his plans and possession of a firearm, leading to an early interception at the airport.
Cagle was found in a Chevrolet pickup truck outside the airport terminal with an AR-15 assault rifle and 27 rounds of ammunition.
Cagle is charged with making terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assault, possession of a firearm during commission of a felony, and possession of a firearm by a felon.
The incident was averted due to early warning from family members, highlighting the importance of community vigilance and social media monitoring.
Cagle has a history of mental health struggles, including schizophrenia, and had previously expressed his condition on social media.
Authorities are investigating how he obtained the firearm, which was illegally possessed due to his status as a convicted felon.
The city and federal authorities, including Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem, praised the swift action of law enforcement in preventing a tragedy.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Billy Joe Cagle, a 49-year-old convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted authorities that he had planned to shoot up the airport on a social media livestream. Police found an AR-15 assault rifle and 27 rounds of ammunition in his Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the terminal. Cagle, who has a history of mental health issues including schizophrenia, was taken into custody and charged with making terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assault, and possession of firearms by a felon. The incident was averted due to early intervention by family members and law enforcement, with officials praising the role of community vigilance and the swift action taken to prevent a potential mass shooting. Authorities are investigating how Cagle legally obtained the firearm, which was prohibited due to his felony status.
title: Man Arrested at Atlanta Airport After Planning to Shoot Up the Terminal on Social Media Livestream
